newsitem.title: FINLAND: LATER EMU ENTRY NO GOOD FOR FINLAND -MATTI VANHALA.
newsitem.headline: LATER EMU ENTRY NO GOOD FOR FINLAND -MATTI VANHALA.

text.p: Bank of Finland board member Matti Vanhala said on Tuesday that the least satisfactory solution would be for Finland to delay its entry into the European economic and monetary union beyond the 1999 start-up.
"The most difficult would be to say 'Yes, but later'," Vanhala told an EMU seminar arranged by the Metal Workers Union.
Vanhala said that once a country decides either to join or stay out of EMU, "financial markets would begin to act accordingly."
Regardless of a country's long-term propsects for joining EMU, during the transition phase, those opting out would be vulnerable to interest rate disturbances, Vanhala said.
Vanhala said Europe's current fragmented monetary situation fed speculation.

"Every exchange rate and interest rate movement makes it possible to speculate," Vanhala said, and added that it was reasonable to assume that monetary conditions would be more stable in the single currency area.
Vanhala said that monetary union should be judged on whether it was likely to bring stable monetary conditions.
The stability pact for EMU added no major obligations to what was already agreed in the Maastrict treaty, Vanhala said.
He said that Finland's own deficit reduction objectives in any case went beyond the requirements for EMU.
"Our goal has been that the public sector should move close to equilibrium," Vanhala said.
